eight pillars in the eight pillars tab first one fiveyear pe ratio less than 22.5 what i did here was take the current market cap of the company 3.22 and i divide it by the total earnings of the last capital basically the invested capital is how much cash flow the business is making based on the money invested in the business in terms of equity and debt take the last five years of the free cash flow divided by the current equity and debt and the last quarter that's our roic for the last 5 years shares outstanding very simple high the shares outstanding this last quarter versus 5 years ago quarter that's simple if it's less than it's a check if it's greater than it's an x cash flow growth in the last 5 years very simple has there been more cash flow this last 12 months versus five years revenue in the last 12 months versus 5 years ago very simple now long-term liabilities divided by 5year free cash flow divid by five so i take the total longterm liabilities on the balance sheet i take the average fiveyear free cash flow i divide the long-term liabilities by the fiveyear free cash flow if it's less than five it's a check if it's more than five it's an x for microsoft it's kind: captions language: en schwab asset management has announced a three for one stock split for 20 of their etfs including the ever so popular sc chd to make it cheaper for investors to purchase shares now on paper sd shares will look cheaper but i'm going to share the truth about stock splits and how this may actually affectd currently sd trades at $84 per share which means the split where to happen today on 3 for one the share price would be closer to around $28 per share sc is a blend of the higher yield dividend companies matching the dow 100 dividend companies the current dividend yield ond is 3.5% sd has a total of 103 positions and the top 10 holdings alone make up 40% of the etf now here's actually the list of the top 25 holdings ford and as you can see there companies you know home depot verizon black rock cisco texas instruments all the way down here this is their percent weight from 4.3% all the way down to 1.14% now it's very important to remember dividends are a fun thing to get i recently did a video about how i'm coming into some money from the sale of a company and i plan on trying to live off this money the rest of my life now since then i've gotten so many messages on instagram on twitter and by the way follow me on those if you want to interact about people saying finally you see the point of dividend no i'm taking taking a portion of my net worth to live off of to get a little bit of capital growth to generate income through dividends and options to live off of this is not my investment remember guys dividends feel wonderful and great but dividends are one of five things that a company can do with its free cash flow you have to remember dividends are highly tax inefficient in order to pay a dividend the company has to have cash flow that cash flow is generated after they've already paid their corporate income taxes then you get the dividend and you know what you do from there you pay another tax on top of that so whenever i hear people say oh it's unfair that dividends are going to rich people and they're only taxed at the lower capital gains rate yeah but if they own the company they're being tax twice there so it's really important to understand that although dividends are wonderful and great to feel they don't actually make you richer you're taking from a company that you own a piece of and put it into your pocket but you've also paid taxes on that when the cash stays in the company a lot of people have a hard time remembering and understanding this when the cash stays in the company you have an ownership stake in that cash so theoretically you're actually less wealthy because you've already paid that dividend now of course a lot of people would say well no wait a second paul i get that cash it can ever be taken away from me i'll give you that of course the money sits in the in the company's accounts they can go spend it on bad things or good things the point is a company should only pay a dividend in my opinion if it's the last resort for the company because remember there are five things you can do with a company's cash flow pay a dividend buy back shares invest in yourself make ac acquisitions or pay down debt i do believe that dividend should be the last thing done with the company's money now remember a lot of brokerages have fractional shares of stocks and etfs so you might be wondering why would schwab do this split remember what a stock split actually does it takes a piece of pie if you have a piece of pie right here cut into four pieces this is the size of the pie all stock split does is if it's a two for one makes it into eight pieces has the size of the pie changed not at all but people always think that makes the stock cheaper it does not it makes the price of the stock lower so you can buy more shares but now instead of buying with sd's uh purpose instead of buying one share you're getting three shares that's it so everybody who owns a hd right now if you own one share of stock you get an additional two more if you own 10 you get 20 more it's taking your ownership and 3x in it that's it the fundamentals behind the companies in the portfolio have not changed they're still generating cash flow they're still doing it on their own basis all you're doing is allowing the stock and etf to be able to be accessed so you can feel richer by owning more shares that's it it is not actually making you wealthier it is not making the etf for the stock better especially with an etf none of these companies have changed none of these companies did a stock split because ofd stock split none of this happened now remember going back to this i love the fact that these etfs low expense ratio this actually lower than spy great dividend yield and this assumes that the stock state these current levels of pricing so you look at as going let's say the market pulls back quite a bit lot of these stocks fall 30% this dividend yield is going to jump up this could jump up close to 5% that's a big dividend yield and it feels good and i always tell people if you're closer to retirement you want some capital growth and you want some income this is a great option i'm not going to lie to you though i do chuckle when i see people who are younger investing in sd if you're young you should want to invest in companies that can take their cash and keep compounding high returns on invested capital is what you should want to get so let's look at the history ofd relative to the performance of the s&p 500 because it's really really important understand that since sd started back in 2011 this is its performant versus the s&p 500 the s&p 500 total return including dividends has been 52% sd 407 this is a big difference but i want everybody to keep in mind the split started basically in 2023 until then it was pretty close but as you can tell sd was always tra trailing and i think that's going to be the case ford in the future it is going to trail the s&p 500 why because the companies that pay a lot of dividends tend to be very very mature companies that can't really grow their earnings per share and their revenue at high rates with the s&p 500 though there'll be a lot of companies in there that aren't paying dividends that are reinvesting their cash to generate more and more profit so naturally their profit should go faster their revenue should go faster and therefore the market cap of the company should grow faster you're seeing that here now since this occurred what's happened here you've had nvidia you've had all the mag 7 absolutely pull away so we really don't have a bare market really to look at here but i will tell you this this bare market here scd did not do as bad as the s&p 500 during the covid crash so i do think it's a way to kind of even out some more returns don't don't get me wrong this still went down a lot during co but it wasn't as bad as the s&p 500 and my guess is when there is finally a bare market the max 7 and all the highflying stocks that drove the s&p values up will probably fall a lot bigger than the scd numbers but again if your goal is capital growth which it should be allow yourself to compound at high rates of higher rates of return without paying taxes i don't know if sd is the right move for you now everybody's position is totally different and as you remember from our last video i am putting a portion of my net worth in scd to live off of the rest of my life because i don't want to touch the cash of my real estate i don't want to touch the cash that i generate from this youtube channel i want to reinvest it to get higher higher rates of return i want to be able to take a portion of my net worth have it sit there and do nothing with it except live off of it that way i can focus my business on reinvesting and building a bigger business that's the big key there i don't want to have my businesses pay me out dividends when i can reinvest that money at high rates of return so if you want more det detail on why i'm buying sd i really encourage you to watch our next video but i also want you to remember that it is not me sitting there saying thatd and dividend stocks are the way to go i'm still being consistent if you told me to put 100% of my net worth in sd at this point in my life with all my businesses going i'd say that's not even worth it but there's a time and place for some investments and you might find some value in that thank you for your time
